Award.AwardTitle: Modelling the Impact of Stellar Feedback on Astrochemistry in Molecular Clouds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stars form within regions of cold, dense molecular gas. Many outstanding problems in star formation, including the origin of star masses and the rate of star formation, rely on first, accurately determining how much molecular gas there is and, second, how energetic that gas is. However, there is no single perfect tracer for all gas densities and temperatures. The most abundant molecule within molecular clouds, molecular hydrogen (H2), is virtually invisible. Consequently, obtaining fundamental information requires understanding the relation between H2 and the emission of other less abundant species, which are all complex functions of the local environment. This research will provide a basis for understanding chemical distributions in different star-forming environments and will focus on the relationship between H2 and easily observable molecules, such as carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen cyanide (HCN).

The goal of this research project is to investigate the evolution of chemical abundances and line emission in star-forming molecular clouds as a function of star formation activity. The investigator will perform numerical simulations of turbulent, star-forming clouds that include magneto-hydrodynamics, radiative transfer, gravity and feedback from stars. This project will use full chemical networks coupled with multi-physics molecular cloud simulations to study the relationship between observations and underlying physical quantities. The investigator will quantitatively explore three fundamental questions: How does the relation between atomic carbon, CO, and HCN emission and H2 density evolve as a function of star formation activity? How well do tracers, such as CO and HCN, probe the gas energetics and correlate with total star formation? What is the impact of kinematic feedback due to proto-stellar outflows on astrochemistry?

This work has implications for estimating the total molecular gas mass, star formation efficiency, and the correspondence between molecular cloud properties (temperature, mass, velocity dispersion) and the star formation rate. They plan to archive and share the abundance and emission maps with the astronomy community through the website "Dataverse". This will allow comparison with observations, including Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) data, for a wide range of species, cloud conditions, and physical scales. New numerical methods developed under the auspices of this funding will also be publicly released.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stars form within regions of cold, dense molecular gas. Many open problems in star formation, including the origin of star masses and the rate of star formation, rely on accurately determining, first, how much molecular gas there is and, second, how energetic that gas is. However, there is no single perfect tracer for all gas densities and temperatures. The most abundant molecule within molecular clouds, H2, is virtually invisible since it does not emit radiation at cold temperatures. Consequently, obtaining basic information about star-forming regions requires understanding the relationship between the amount of molecular hydrogen and the radiation emitted by other less abundant species. Unfortunately, this relationship is complex and depends on the local conditions. In particular, forming stars shape their environment by heating the gas nearby and accelerating high-energy particles: "stellar feedback". Both feedback effects strongly shape the local gas chemistry. 

This research investigated how chemistry and the light emitted from a variety of atoms and molecules change as a function of star formation activity.  The models developed under the auspices of this grant provided a means to understand gas chemistry in different star-forming environments and, in particular, how the relationship between H2 and observationally critical species, such as C, CO and HCN, vary as a function of star formation rate.  Overall, this work improved understanding of how stars like our Sun form.

All new code developed was publicly released. Two public web interfaces were created to compute properties of forming star clusters based on the new models. A python package to analyze and compare molecular observations of star-forming regions was developed and released (Turbustat). A machine learning code to classify "bubble" features produced by young stars was updated (Brut) and released with new training sets.  A new method was developed to couple chemistry calculations with multi-physics, 3D gas simulations including stellar feedback in order to study of the relationship between gas conditions and telescope observations (to be released 2021).

This NSF funding supported research training for two undergraduate students and two graduate students, which included the completion of an astronomy PhD thesis and an undergraduate astronomy senior thesis. Public talks were given on the research program results. The PI worked with undergraduates in astronomy classes to create WorldWide Telescope tours on basic astronomy concepts. The tours created by the students and PI were posted online as a public astronomy education resource.
